newdata 0.0.0.9018

New Sequence

Source: R/new-seq.R
new_seq.Rd

Generate a new sequence for a vector

new_seq(x, length_out = 30)

Arguments

x

The vector to generate the sequence for.

length_out

The length of the sequence.

Value

A vector of the same class as the vector.

See also

new_value() and new_data().

Examples

new_seq(c(1,4,NA)) # returns vector of 30 equidistant real values in range
#>  [1] 1.000000 1.103448 1.206897 1.310345 1.413793 1.517241 1.620690 1.724138
#>  [9] 1.827586 1.931034 2.034483 2.137931 2.241379 2.344828 2.448276 2.551724
#> [17] 2.655172 2.758621 2.862069 2.965517 3.068966 3.172414 3.275862 3.379310
#> [25] 3.482759 3.586207 3.689655 3.793103 3.896552 4.000000
new_seq(c(1,4,NA),  length_out = 10) # returns 10 equidistant real values
#>  [1] 1.000000 1.333333 1.666667 2.000000 2.333333 2.666667 3.000000 3.333333
#>  [9] 3.666667 4.000000
new_seq(c(1L,4L,NA)) # returns up to 30 unique integer values
#> [1] 1 2 3 4
new_seq(c(1L,4L,NA), length_out = 3) # up to three unique integer values
#> [1] 1 2 4
new_seq(c(1L,4L,NA), length_out = 2) # minimum and maximum integer values
#> [1] 1 4
new_seq(c(1L,4L,NA), length_out = 1) # minimum integer value
#> [1] 1
new_seq(c("g", "a", "b", "b", NA)) # all character values
#> [1] "a" "b" "g"
# all factor levels preserving factor levels
new_seq(factor(c("g", "a", "b", "b", NA), levels = c("b", "a", "g")))
#> [1] b a g
#> Levels: b a g
# rounded mean for dates and times
new_seq(as.Date(c("2000-01-01", "2000-01-04", NA)))
#> [1] "2000-01-01" "2000-01-02" "2000-01-03" "2000-01-04"
new_seq(hms::as_hms(c("00:00:01", "00:00:04", NA)))
#> 00:00:01
#> 00:00:02
#> 00:00:03
#> 00:00:04
new_seq(as.POSIXct(c("2000-01-01 00:00:01", "2000-01-01 00:00:04", NA)))
#> [1] "2000-01-01 00:00:01 UTC" "2000-01-01 00:00:02 UTC"
#> [3] "2000-01-01 00:00:03 UTC" "2000-01-01 00:00:04 UTC"
new_seq(c(TRUE,FALSE, NA))
#> [1] FALSE  TRUE
